title: Tariff Retaliation Cascade
context: A country imposes tariffs on imports to protect domestic industries and reduce trade deficits. The first-order effect is straightforward: imported goods become more expensive, domestic producers gain a price advantage. But trading partners retaliate with their own tariffs. Supply chains reorganize. Consumers pay more. The industries the tariffs were meant to protect often end up worse off as their export markets shrink and input costs rise.
hypothesis: Tariffs protect domestic industries and reduce trade deficits by making imports more expensive.

children.label: Export markets shrink for domestic producers
Agricultural sector hit hardest — perishable goods can't wait out trade wars
Retaliation targets politically sensitive industries for maximum pressure

effects.label: Consumer prices rise across the economy
effects.impact: Tariff cost passed through 90-100% to consumers

children.label: Low-income households hit hardest — tariffs are regressive taxes
Downstream manufacturers pay more for inputs

effects.label: Supply chains reorganize — but not to domestic production
effects.impact: Trade diverts to third countries, not home

children.label: Manufacturing moves to Vietnam, Mexico, India — not back home
Supply chain complexity increases, not decreases
Transition costs and delays disrupt production for years

effects.label: Trade deficit persists or worsens
effects.impact: No sustained deficit reduction in historical cases

children.label: Deficit shifts to different countries rather than shrinking

dontIf: Your domestic industry depends on imported inputs that will also be tariffed
Your major trading partners have credible retaliation capacity
ifYouMust: Target tariffs narrowly at specific products, not broad categories
Set explicit sunset dates — tariffs should be temporary, not permanent
Pair tariffs with domestic investment in the protected industry's competitiveness
Negotiate exemptions for critical inputs that domestic producers need

alternatives.name: Industrial policy and subsidies
alternatives.note: Invest directly in domestic capacity rather than taxing imports

alternatives.name: Trade adjustment assistance
alternatives.note: Help displaced workers transition rather than protecting uncompetitive industries

alternatives.name: Multilateral trade agreements
alternatives.note: Negotiate market access collectively rather than through bilateral tariff wars

seo.description: Tariffs trigger retaliation 85% of the time, raise consumer prices 10-25%, and destroy 5x more jobs in downstream sectors than they create. Trade deficits persist regardless.
